Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Secondary Thrombocytosis due to an underlying infection or inflammation
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug Reactions (e.g., Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms - DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, kidneys, blood cells, joints, and lungs. Symptoms like malar rash, pleural effusion, synovitis, nephritis, and leukopenia are common in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder primarily affecting joints but can also involve other tissues; pleural effusion and synovitis are common, and it can occasionally cause leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease with features overlapping SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, including synovitis and nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the body's moisture-producing glands; it's less commonly associated with nephritis and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases causing hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can affect internal organs and potentially lead to nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease where small and medium-sized arteries become swollen and damaged. While not the most common, it can feature some of the symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. Though not directly associated with leukopenia, nephritis or pleural effusion, overlaps in autoimmune disorders can present similarly.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the kidneys caused by SLE, directly relevant due to the symptom of nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause organ and system damage, potentially including kidney damage (nephritis) and affecting the lungs.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A lupus-like syndrome that is caused by certain prescription drugs. Symptoms can mirror those of SLE, including leukopenia, malar rash, and potentially affecting the kidneys and lungs.

diagnoses: Pneumocystis Pneumonia (in the context of immune compromise, e.g., HIV)
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) with extraesophageal manifestations

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, and can cause complications. This can indirectly relate to symptoms like congestion due to increased blood volume and possibly affect mood or cause depression due to systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Depression (Dysthymia)
diagnoses.description: A persistent form of depression where a person may experience symptoms for years, which can impact daily life significantly. It might not directly cause polycythemia but can be comorbid with other systemic symptoms or conditions.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly. Decreased immunoglobulins are a hallmark, possibly leading to congestion due to frequent infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Fatigue may coexist with symptoms like depression and can be associated with immune system problems.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disease
diagnoses.description: Diseases where the immune system attacks healthy cells in the body by mistake. Some autoimmune disorders could potentially explain the combination of symptoms like depression, decreased immunoglobulins, and potentially vulvodynia due to inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It can be associated with decreased immunoglobulins and systemic symptoms, including fatigue which can be perceived as depression.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (CIRS)
diagnoses.description: CIRS is a chronic condition of prolonged or excessive inflammation in the body, potentially affecting multiple systems and possibly leading to a broad range of symptoms, including those presented.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It doesn't directly cause polycythemia but could be associated with depression and possibly vulvodynia due to pain processing disorders.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Although typically associated with low hemoglobin levels, in rare cases, iron deficiency has been linked to an increase in red blood cell production after iron supplementation, which could mimic polycythemia. It could coexist with depression and immune dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism's broad symptom profile can include fatigue (mistaken for depression), weight gain, and potentially affect immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by low levels of clotting protein in the blood.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that occurs when blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells due to insufficient iron.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A potentially severe sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep.

diagnoses.name: Coagulation Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the blood's ability to clot, which can lead to prolonged bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormone imbalance problem that can interfere with normal ovulation and can cause abnormal bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Diseases that impair liver function, potentially leading to a variety of symptoms and complications including issues with clotting and hormone regulation.

diagnoses.name: Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by abnormally low levels of platelets, the cells that help blood clot.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by excessive worry and anxiety, occurring more days than not for at least six months, about a number of activities or events.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that often accompanies other immune system disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. It involves the destruction of glands that produce tears and saliva, leading to dry eyes and mouth.

diagnoses.name: Rosacea
diagnoses.description: A common skin condition that causes redness and visible blood vessels in your face. It may also produce small, red, pus-filled bumps.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis (Eczema)
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Atopic dermatitis is long lasting (chronic) and tends to flare periodically.

diagnoses.name: Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A form of lupus that is limited to the skin and is characterized by rash and lesions. These lesions may become thick and scaly, causing scarring.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A group of blood cancers that develop from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. It can cause lymphadenopathy (swollen glands), weight loss, and sweating.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells, due to a lack of iron. This leads to insufficient oxygen being carried around the body, causing fatigue, pallor, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer of the lymphatic system. It can affect anyone, but is most common between ages 20 and 40, and after age 55.

diagnoses.name: Relapsing Polychondritis
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of inflammation of cartilage and other tissues throughout the body. It can cause redness, swelling, and irritation in the eyes, among other symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Infectious diseases (e.g., viral, bacterial, fungal, parasitic infections)

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. Having anemia can make you feel tired and weak.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. Also called major depressive disorder or clinical depression, it affects how you feel, think and behave and can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels. The ovaries may develop numerous small collections of fluid (follicles) and fail to regularly release eggs.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia — a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells. Red blood cells carry oxygen to the body's tissues. As the name implies, iron deficiency anemia is due to insufficient iron.

diagnoses.name: General Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by chronic anxiety, exaggerated worry, and tension, even when there is little or nothing to provoke it.

diagnoses.name: Allergies
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the immune system reacts abnormally to a foreign substance. Symptoms of an allergy include sneezing, itching, watery eyes, and in some cases, decreased libido as part of the systemic reaction.

diagnoses.name: Hypogonadism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the body doesn't produce enough of the sex hormones (testosterone in men, estrogen and progesterone in women). This can lead to a decrease in libido among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that attacks your respiratory system — your nose, throat and lungs. Influenza is commonly called the flu, but it's not the same as stomach 'flu' viruses that cause diarrhea and vomiting.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark symptom, and diabetes can also affect water retention, leading to edema. It can occasionally cause dysgeusia due to alterations in metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to hyperglycemia if diabetes is the underlying cause, and is associated with edema due to fluid retention. Dysgeusia can occur due to uremia.

diagnoses.name: Liver Cirrhosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance. Edema and bloating are common due to portal hypertension and hypoalbuminemia. Dysgeusia can occur due to altered metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.reasoning: May present with migratory edema due to fluid congestion. Diabetes is a common comorbidity that might explain hyperglycemia. Heart failure can cause liver congestion leading to symptoms such as bloating.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause hyperglycemia, bloating, and edema due to slowed metabolism and reduced kidney function. Dysgeusia is also a reported symptom due to altered perception.

diagnoses.name: Cushing Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by hyperglycemia due to increased cortisol levels. Edema and bloating are common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Venous Insufficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Primarily causes edema but can indirectly affect other systems. Not directly associated with hyperglycemia but can coincide in patients with comorbid conditions.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiencies
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain deficiencies can lead to dysgeusia (e.g., zinc) and bloating (due to malabsorption). Not typically associated with hyperglycemia but can co-occur in malnutrition.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Conditions such as celiac disease or Crohn's disease can cause bloating and dysgeusia. They can alter nutrient absorption, potentially impacting blood sugar levels indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Acromegaly
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance. Additional symptoms like soft tissue swelling can mimic edema. Bloating and dysgeusia can also occur due to gastrointestinal enlargement and hormonal changes.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.reasoning: Presents with depression as a primary symptom, which may affect mood and cause mood lability.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause a wide range of symptoms including depression, lymphadenitis, and hypersensitivity reactions. Abdominal pain could be related to lupus enteritis.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause mood lability and depression. Migratory abdominal pain might be related to stress or anxiety-related gastrointestinal issues.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Lymphadenitis is a common symptom. Patients might experience depressive symptoms and mood lability due to the stress of dealing with a chronic illness.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Can present with lymphadenitis. Depression and mood lability are common in chronic illnesses. Hypersensitivity reactions might occur due to medications or opportunistic infections.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause mood lability, depression, and hypersensitivity reactions. It can also lead to abdominal pain due to gastrointestinal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause lymphadenitis and hypersensitivity reactions such as erythema nodosum. Depression and mood lability might occur as part of the systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Patients often report depression and mood lability. Abdominal pain and hypersensitivity reactions can also be symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by mood lability, depression, and somatic symptoms such as abdominal pain. Patients may also report hypersensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Functional Gastrointestinal Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause migratory abdominal pain. Depression and mood lability are often associated with or exacerbated by these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, causing weakness and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.details: Also known as high blood pressure, can lead to headache and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.details: A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Pressure from the tumor can cause tinnitus and balance problems.

diagnoses.name: Meniere’s Disease
diagnoses.details: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In many cases, there is also a ringing in the ear (tinnitus) or head.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). Symptoms can include fatigue, limited mobility, and tinnitus as a less common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency
diagnoses.details: Insufficient iron can lead to anemia, causing fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause headaches and other symptoms depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Temporomandibular Joint Disorders (TMJ)
diagnoses.details: Disorders of the jaw joint and chewing muscles that can cause pain around the ears, headaches, and sometimes tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: Severe, recurring headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye, accompanied by symptoms such as redness of the eye, tearing, and nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Tension Headaches
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by pressure or tightness around the forehead or back of the head and neck.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. Weakness is a common symptom, and headache can occur.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that can cause visual disturbances, weakness, and sensory problems.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. Symptoms include severe headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering the brain. Symptoms often include a sudden, severe headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. It can cause headaches, weakness, and a variety of other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Viral Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain caused by a virus. Symptoms can include headache, photophobia, weakness, and altered mental status.

diagnoses.name: Acute Angle-Closure Glaucoma
diagnoses.description: A sudden increase in eye pressure causing intense pain, blurred vision, headache, and occasionally nausea. Photophobia may also be present.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is accompanied by visual disturbances (scintillation), sensitivity to sound (phonophobia), and can sometimes lead to temporary motor weakness or coordination issues (ataxia).

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. People with Meniere’s may experience a feeling of fullness in the affected ear.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that may cause vertigo, dizziness, and balance problems (ataxia), along with the more typical migraine symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Tumors in certain parts of the brain can press on nerves that control motor function or hearing, leading to symptoms like ataxia and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, leading to symptoms like ataxia, tingling, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that can cause hearing loss, balance problems (ataxia), and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke can affect any part of the brain, leading to various symptoms including ataxia and sometimes hearing loss, depending on the area of the brain that is affected.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it can cause temporary symptoms similar to a stroke, such as ataxia, but usually resolves within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Ototoxicity
diagnoses.description: Damage to the hearing or balance organs of the inner ear caused by exposure to certain chemicals or medications, leading to hearing loss and balance problems (ataxia).

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Ataxias
diagnoses.description: A group of genetic disorders that affect coordination and balance (ataxia), and in some cases, can also cause hearing loss.

diagnoses.comments: Combination of photophobia, scintillation, and vomiting fits a classic migraine presentation; hearing loss is less common but can occur.
Symptoms including vomiting, weakness, photophobia, and, less commonly, hearing loss could suggest an infectious cause like meningitis.
An inner ear condition that can cause hearing loss, weakness (imbalance), and vomiting; photophobia isn't a hallmark symptom but can be present due to general discomfort and malaise.
Similar to labyrinthitis, causing hearing loss, vomiting, and a sense of imbalance; photophobia and scintillation could be present in severe cases.

A chronic condition that can present with a wide array of symptoms including weakness, scintillation (as in optic neuritis), and, less commonly, photophobia; vomiting and hearing loss are not typical but can occur.
Depending on its location, can cause a variety of symptoms including hearing loss, vomiting (especially in the morning), weakness, photophobia, and visual disturbances like scintillation.
Certain toxins or drugs can lead to vomiting, weakness, photophobia, and visual disturbances; hearing loss is less commonly associated but possible with certain substances.
An infection of the brain causing symptoms such as vomiting, photophobia, scintillation, hearing loss, and general weakness.
Can cause rapidly progressive hearing loss, and in severe cases, associated symptoms might include general weakness and vomiting; photophobia and scintillation are less common.

Mainly manifests with vertigo which might lead to vomiting; associated weakness due to vertigo, while photophobia and scintillation are not classic symptoms but could be present due to migraine overlap in some individuals.

diagnoses: Vasculitis syndromes (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Microscopic polyangiitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. The combination of synovitis, nonscarring alopecia, photosensitive rash, and hemolytic anemia fits well with the clinical spectrum of SLE.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: While primarily known as a chronic inflammatory disorder affecting the joints, rheumatoid arthritis can also manifest with systemic features such as anemia. However, the specific combination of symptoms listed fits less typically with rheumatoid arthritis compared to SLE.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rashes, including photosensitive rashes. However, it is less commonly associated with hemolytic anemia and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that typically affects the glands that produce tears and saliva but can also cause joint pain and skin rashes. Hemolytic anemia and nonscarring alopecia are less commonly seen.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus Tumidus
diagnoses.description: A form of cutaneous lupus erythematosus presenting with photosensitive rash without the presence of epidermal involvement like discoid lupus. Alopecia and systemic symptoms such as synovitis and anemia may be present in more systemic cases.

diagnoses.name: Discoid Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease primarily affecting the skin but can present with systemic symptoms in more severe cases. Patients might exhibit photosensitive rash and nonscarring alopecia, but hemolytic anemia and synovitis are more indicative of systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A disease presenting features of three connective tissue diseases — lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis — including symptoms like those described. It involves the inflammation of muscles, joints, and skin.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. It's less commonly associated with the skin and joint symptoms detailed but remains a differential diagnosis given the hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A lupus-like syndrome triggered by certain drugs. Symptoms often mimic those of systemic lupus erythematosus, including joint pain (synovitis), skin rash (photosensitive rash), and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing low platelet counts, leading to easy bruising and bleeding. While its primary association is with platelets, autoimmune conditions like ITP can occasionally present with systemic symptoms, though the combination of symptoms listed would be rare.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Chronic Kidney Disease due to Glomerulonephritis
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Chronic Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus (Discoid Lupus Erythematosus)
